abstract: A return of Libyan oil production to levels before the unrest would take until 2015, according to one estimate. The forecast may now be too pessimistic.
snippet: A return of Libyan oil production to levels before the unrest would take until 2015, according to one estimate. The forecast may now be too pessimistic.
lead_paragraph: The endgame in Libya could herald a slump in oil prices. As with the rebel advance into Tripoli, Libyan supplies to the global market could come sooner than expected. Brent crude prices slipped by as much as $3 to almost $106 a barrel at one point on Monday, before rebounding later in the day. A resolution in Libya, coupled with concerns over global growth, means tight markets could soon look oversupplied.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

byline.original: By Una Galani and Reynolds Holding
